Description: The project is for the reconstruction of approximately 4.7 kilometres of York Road, from Shannonville Road to Norways Road, and includes engineering design and inspection of the project, geotechnical investigation, excavation and disposal of existing base material, removal and replacement of cross-culverts where required, and road reconstruction including paved shoulders, as well as the rehabilitation of Mud Creek Bridge including repair of box girder ends, replacement of deck drains, deck and concrete repairs, replacement of joint seal and associated works, waterproofing and repaving.
Rehabilitation of Matheson Drive, from the western municipal boundary to Rosedale Road South.

Project: Replacement of the Blind Bridge on Abraham Line
Description: The Project will replace the Blind Bridge on Abraham Line in Morris-Turnberry.The work will involve removing the existing, one-lane bridge and constructing a new, two-lane structure. Approximately 80 metres of road approach work will be completed on both the north and south sides of the bridge.  Erosion protection and guide rail on both sides of the approaches to each end of the structure will also be included.

Description: The Project will rehabilitate the access road between Highway 71 and the First Nation communities of Naotkamegwanning, Animakee Wa Zhing #37 and Northwest Angle #33.The work involves upgrading approximately 3.6 kilometres of Blue Mountain Drive and Main Drive, including rebuilding the subgrade; improving drainage though grading, ditching and the replacement of two culverts; removing overgrowth on the shoulders; resurfacing with bituminous treatment; replacing guiderails and posts; and installing additional signage.
Result: Overall, the project will improve the reliability and safety of the road and contribute to better the overall road network.

Description: Upgrades to Deadman Bridge, including restoration of existing concrete deck topping, installation of new deck expansion joints, replaced safety grates, repairs to bottoms of box girders and installation of steel beam guiderails on the bridge approaches

Description: The Project will reconstruct approximately 2.5 kilometres of Drummond Road (Thorold Stone Road to Morrison Street),Gallinger Street and Portage Road (Elizabeth Street to Althea Street) in Niagara Falls.The work involves rebuilding the road base; adding curbs, gutters and sidewalks with tactile warning plates for people with disabilities; installing dedicated bike lanes and street lighting; improving turning radii at intersections, including a dedicated right turn lane at Morrison Street; rehabilitating approaches to two railway crossings with upgraded safety warning systems and signage; and repaving the roads.  Expenditures related to underground infrastructure are ineligible for reimbursement.

Project: Replacement of Big Creek Bridge on Long Point Causeway
Description: The Project will replace Big Creek Bridge with a new structure in Norfolk County.The work involves removing the existing bridge; constructing parapet walls; installing an approximately 34.1-metre, three-span bridge, with precast concrete girders,  pile foundations, a wider concrete deck to safely accommodate two lanes, waterproofing and asphalt wearing surface, paved shoulders, bicycle railings, and ducts for utilities.Approximately 250 metres of approach work will be completed to each of the north and south approaches of the new bridge including approach slabs, grubbing and clearing, earth excavation and grading, granular materials, asphalt, pavement markings, steel beam guide rails and restorations.In addition, William Lane, Hugh Lane, and George Lane including private driveways on the east sides, will be regraded to match the increased elevation required to accommodate the new structure.

Description: The Project is for the reconstruction and expansion of approximately 950 metres of McKeown Avenue, from Gormanville Road to Cartier Street in North Bay. The work involves widening the road from two to four lanes, rehabilitating the subgrade, installing a new sidewalk, reconstructing curb, gutters and boulevards, re-paving the road, replacing an existing sidewalk with a recreational pathway, and adding approximately 100 meters of transition roadway.NOTE: Sanitary and watermain replacement costs are not eligible.
Rehabilitation of Head Road Bridge.
Result: Increased Traffic Safety

Description: The Project is for the reconstruction and upgrade of approximately 1.15 kilometres of County Road 43, from County Road 44/Rideau Street to the Kemptville Creek in North Grenville. The work includes widening the roadway to accommodate four lanes; construction of four roundabouts with controlled pedestrian crossings; rebuilding of curbs and gutters; installing new bike lanes, sidewalks and street lighting; and landscaping non-paved areas. In addition, the rehabilitation of the approximately 39-metre bridge across Kemptville Creek will occur, and includes the rehabilitation of the deck, girders, abutments and parapet wall.

Signage and traffic calming devices will be replaced and added, and flashing amber beacons installed.
Result: These upgrades will improve the safety of motorists and pedestrians.

Description: The Project is for the rehabilitation of approximately 6.7 kilometres of County Road 14, which includes both Yankee Line and the J.A. Gifford Causeway, from Boundary Road to Kelly Boulevard, and includes pavement rehabilitation, installing sidewalks and paved shoulders, replacing deficient guardrails and streetlights, improving drainage, replacement or relining of cross-culverts, as well as repairing the existing  Chemong Bridge located on the causeway.
Result: These improvements will increase safety for motorists and pedestrians, and extend the life of the bridge and roadway.

Description: The Project will reconstruct and expand Pickle Lake Road.  Road reconstruction will begin at the corner of Highway 599 and continue along Pickle Lake Road which merges into Patricia Street and turns into Koval Street for approximately 6.4 kilometres ending at a dead end at the Pickle Lake Airport. This work will involve regrading, widening, resurfacing, ditching and other drainage improvements including the installation of approximately seven culverts.The road expansion will involve building a new access road of approximately 1.3 kilometres which will run from the dead end at Pickle Lake Airport, where the fence and barricade will be removed, east to Highway 599. This new construction would involve clearing trees and stumps, building a roadway, inserting proper drainage, surfacing the roadway, and adding a new intersection at Highway 599.Expenditures related to underground infrastructure are ineligible for reimbursement.
Result: These upgrades will improve road safety, better the flow of traffic and provide a secondary access point for emergency responses. Wider, paved shoulders will also encourage safer active transportation.

Description: The Project will rehabilitate approximately two kilometres of Maple Hill Road in Powassan.  The work area will begin approximately 863 metres north of Highway 534. The work involves aligning and raising the road elevation by approximately 0.6 metres; improving drainage through rock excavation and ditching,  installation of culverts and lining an existing culvert; rehabilitating side slopes to enhance stability using rock protection, rip rap, sheet piles and/or gabion baskets; installing new guide rails that meet provincial standards; and roadway realignment where necessary.

The Project is for the reconstruction of approximately 8.125 kilometres of Alderdale Road in Chisholm. The reconstruction will take place from Chiswick Line to the Chisholm-East Ferris municipal boundary, and includes improvements to the road elevation and ditching, replacement of 12 culverts, pulverizing of the existing hard top, upgraded sub-base and resurfacing of the roadway.

The Project will replace the one-lane McEwing Bridge over Mill Creek with a new, two-lane 52.4-metre structure, and reconstruct approximately 157.6 metres of roadway approaching the bridge in Saugeen Shores.The Project will remove the existing bridge and replace it with a new structure that includes parapet walls, approach slabs, a concrete deck on steel girders, railings, and a guide rail and barrier system. Seeding of the lands surrounding the new bridge and approaches will also be completed.

Description: The Project will convert the intersection of Highway 54 and Chiefswood Road to a single lane roundabout with single lane entry and exit on all four approaches in the Six Nations of the Grand River First Nation.The work will involve installing concrete curbs and gutters, rehabilitating the subgrade, paving the roundabout road and entries, and landscaping the middle of the roundabout and other areas disturbed by construction.

Project: Rehabilitation of the Holt Line Bridge over the Sydenham River
Description: The project will rehabilitate the Holt Line Bridge over the Sydenham River. It includes repairs to the concrete abutments, replacement of the steel members and bearings, reconstruction of ballast walls and possible tie-back of the abutments to resist movement and impinging.  The concrete deck and curb, truss bottom chords and expansion bearings will be replaced.  Erosion control, removal of surface corrosion, painting and improvements to the guiderail system are also included.  Minor restoration work will be completed on the approaches in the immediate area of the bridge to facilitate abutment repairs.

Project: Reconstruction of Roads Wawa School  Zone
Description: The Project will reconstruct nine roads that total approximately 2.5 kilometres in Wawa. Project work will take place on Grace Street, Parkhill Street, Darwin Street, Boyer Street, Ross Street, Spruce Street from Churchill Ave. to Superior Ave., Churchill Ave. from Mission Road to Hillcrest Ave. intersection, Arnott Ave. from Parkhill to Magpie Road, and Magpie Road from Mission Road to Churchill Ave.  The reconstruction will include reparation of frost heaves; drainage improvements; replacement of curbs, gutters, sidewalks and ramps; resurfacing of roads; and repainting of pavement markers. In addition, the project will install pedestrian crossings, bike lanes, sidewalks, a bus loading zone and parking.
Result: These upgrades will improve safety and reliability, support better traffic flow, and facilitate active transportation.

Project: Construction of the Former Welland Canal Crossing
Description: The Project will replace the former Forks Road Bridge lift structure over the Welland Canal in Welland.The work will involve building a new bridge with a span of approximately 124 meters, installing new abutments, and approach work to elevate/widen the existing road to match the new structure as required.
Result: Improved public health and safety concerns, traffic flow for motorist and pedestrians, emergency response, and reduce the probability of asset failure and service interruptions.

Description: Restoring Cst. Rick Hopkins Bridge
Result: New deck and railings, pavement, curbs and sidewalks

Description: The project will replace the single lane, 15-metre Lantz bridge with a wider, two-lane wooden bridge. Project work will include; strip and stockpile soil, removal of the existing structure, dewatering and excavation and installation of foundations.  Wooden girders and deck will be installed and bridge approaches will be reconstructed and widened.  Site restoration work and clean-up will also be included.

The Project will rehabilitate approximately 1.5 kilometers of St. Ann’s Road between Twenty Mile Road and Regional Road Twenty, and upgrade the 31 metre, St. Ann’s Bridge (Bridge 46) in West Lincoln.The road rehabilitation will involve installing of driveway culverts, a curb and gutter system and ditching to address roadway drainage; replacing and widening sidewalks; improving the railway crossing to meet regulatory requirements; installing new guiderails; relocating utilities (gas, hydro, telecommunications); rebuilding the granular sub-base and repaving the road. In addition, the upgrade to St. Ann’s Bridge will include patch repairs to the substructure, erosion protection, deck improvements, and replacement of the barrier walls and deck sidewalk.

Project: Rehabilitation of Leblanc and Lalande Roads
Description: Rehabilitation of Leblanc Road, from Bay Street to Lalande Road, and Lalande Road, from Leblanc Road to Fort Road.
Result: Increased traffic safety

Project: Rehabilitation of Lyndale Road and Black's Trail
Description: The Project will rehabilitate Lyndale Road from Highway 631 for approximately 2.3 kilometres and Black’s Trail from Lyndale Road for approximately 0.9 kilometres in White River.The work involves replacing the road base, regrading, adjusting horizontal and vertical alignments and lane width as required, reconfiguring an intersection, improving drainage by ditching and replacing culverts, and constructing two turn-around areas for snow plows.
Replacement of Holland Mills Road Bridge.
Result: Increased traffic safety

Project: Replacement of Structure 34/B-T9 over the Nith River
Description: The Project will replace bridge 34/B-T9 which is a 45-metre, one-lane bridge with a new, two-lane concrete structure in the Township of Wilmot.  The work will involve the removal of the existing structure and abutments; building a new foundation, abutments, and superstructure with a reinforced concrete deck and barrier walls, as well as approach work on either side of the bridge including a redesign of the vertical alignment to accommodate the bridge elevation. Bridge Street will be widened to a two-lane approach with shouldering, guiderails, and safety attenuators will be installed.  Erosion and sediment control measures will also be added.
Result: Improved load, width, and height restrictions at this bridge.

Description: Construction of cross-dock cargo facility, together with all associated airside and groundside airport infrastructure
Result: New centre to support growing air cargo business at Hamilton Airport

Project: Municipal Airport Terminal Building Expansion and Renovation
Description: Includes functional upgrades as well as addressing safety-related deficiencies
Result: Improved safety and efficiency

Project: Lakehead University - New Centre for Advanced Studies in Engineering and Sciences
Description: Construction of a $22.1 million new addition on an existing building for the Centre for Advanced Studies in Engineering and Sciences (CASES).  Within this space, 15,700 square feet will be constructed to support innovative research and commercialization for the development of green materials, value-added products, advanced technologies, and environmentally compatible solutions for tapping into the natural resources of Northern Ontario.
Result: CASES has allowed Lakehead University to modernize and expand an existing building to create a new sustainably designed research complex that addresses a lack of research and advanced training space at its Thunder Bay campus. The Project has greatly advanced Lakehead's research and innovation capacity, will accommodate training of over 600 graduate students and highly qualified personnel (HQP), and will support the creation of new advanced jobs and business start-ups to accelerate entrepreneurial and economic outcomes regionally and nationally.

Project: Crowley Lake Trail Expansion at Kivi Park
Description: Complete a 15.9-kilometre muti-use trail expansion around Crowley Lake and Linton Lake.
Result: Connecting both Kivi Park properties (Main Kivi Park Area and Crowley Lake access trails) and all Kivi trails into a single network, will benefit the community by increasing the ease and efficiency of trail and visitor use, trail maintenance, and trail safety. It will also expand the Park trail network for both the Para Nordic athletes and able-bodied athletes who use Kivi Park as a training center for sports and recreation. Kivi is also heavily utilized by families. This project will provide more opportunities for local families within the community to experience the benefits of outdoor activities in the winter, such as skiing and hiking. In the warmer months, it will be a space for families to create memories and bond in nature. Lastly, this project will help the applicant identify Kivi Park as a Northern Ontario tourism attraction, bringing new people and a new appetite for exploration in the North.

Description: Replace outdated ice-plant mechanical components for three distinct community centres within the Municipality of Greenstone:  Longlac Sportsplex, Nakina Community Centre, and Beardmore Community Centre. Result: The project will result in upgrades to the Longlac community centre within the Municipality of Greenstone.  Extending the life of the asset and improving the quality of life for community residents and the region.

The clubhouse is not only used by those at the course to golf, but also acts as a venue for private functions such as weddings. The elevator in particular will remove barriers to those with physical limitations wanting to use the clubhouse. The course improvements such as the paving of the paths and new maintenance shed will make the course more resilient, attractive, and useable for tourists and residents alike.

Description: Implement Phase 1 of the Point Grondine Eco Resort and Campground Capitalization Project. The Point Grondine Eco Resort and Campground is a First Nations owned and operated destination located in Killarney, where traditional Anishnaabek culture meets a peaceful eco-retreat in one of Ontario's most spectacular regions. By combining family-friendly campgrounds, educational and cultural programming, outdoor recreation opportunities, and access to backcountry journeys, this park hopes to become a unique destination for tourists to the region.
Result: This project will involve planning and design including site engineering, landscape planning and architectural work. It will also involve the development of campsites, parking lot and road work, and the construction a number of buildings, and the purchase of equipment to complete Phase 1 of Point Grondine Park, located in Killarney, Ontario.

Description: Science North's incredible waterfront includes an extensive floating dock attached to a wooden deck boardwalk that forms part of a larger municipal boardwalk (Bell Park). The floating dock was assessed in 2023 and it was determined that the floatation billets were fully saturated and the dock experienced sinking and heaving to the point where it has lost 70% of its floatation capacity (150mm freeboard height compared to the necessary 500mm). The study concluded that the dock was beyond its useful life and recommended a full replacement. The section of boardwalk owned by Science North also requires assessment and repair to extend its useful life. See supporting documents for the detailed assessment report.

Project: Science North: Window Reglazing, Caulking and Replacement
Description: Various locations in the facility are old double pane aluminum frame windows which need to be replaced, as many of them are failing or damaged, and all are not up to modern day energy efficiency standards. The glazing in the large snowflake is nearing 35 years old and numerous windows are failing, leading to water leaks and moisture buildups. There is tremendous energy lost because of this and constant clean-up required because of water leaks. Due to the complications caused by the locations of the windows and the cost of the scaffolding required to replace them, the windows must be replaced all at once.
Upgrade water treatment, shower, washroom and dishwashing systems
Result: Provide better, more secure and accessible facilities

Project: Allandale Mobility Hub - New Transit Terminal & Downtown Connection Hub Planning and Design
Description: The Allandale Mobility Hub will locate the primary bus terminaladjacent to the local GO train station for local and regional transitconnectivity. It will be located within the future geographic centre ofthe City of Barrie with a site that has future growth potential. The sitewill include bus platforms, lay by express bus stops, and a terminalbuilding. The Downtown Connection Hub will function as theprimary bus stop within the Downtown by providing lay by lanes andbus stops with a shelter to serve the Downtown with the relocation ofthe primary terminal to Allandale. This project will be for thePlanning and Design phases to complete the design and designapproval process of the Allandale Mobility Hub – New TransitTerminal and the related Downtown Connection Hub.
Result: Improved connections between GO Train andBarrie Transit service.

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Contract for grading for the second track, installing noise walls and high security fencing, drainage, and utility re-locations, on the southern portion of the corridor between Mile 1.9 to Mile 12.6. Also, Sheppard Avenue Bridge expansion on the west side (new track bridge and new pedestrian bridge), including new west platform Downsview GO Station on the pedestrian bridge)
Address: Barrie corridor  between Mile 1.9 to Mile 12.6

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: The Barrie Contract 2 project involves double tracking along the Barrie corridor from Rutherford (at Mile 17.50) to McNaughton Side Road (at Mile 18.61) as well as the infrastructure improvements at the Maple GO Station. The station improvements include a rehabilitated east platform, a new west side platform and commissioning of the north and south tunnel which includes elevators. The bus loop will be expanded on Eagle Rock Way with a north tunnel connection to the bus loop. Depending on commitments from the City of Vaughan, the scope may include a cycling bridge on the East side of Major MacKenzie, and a pedestrian access from the west side of the corridor on Lindenshire Ave.
Address: Barrie corridor from Rutherford (at Mile 17.50) to McNaughton Side Road (at Mile 18.61)

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: The Barrie Contract 3 project includes grading from Mi 21.1 to 29.17, 7km of noise walls, fencing, culvert extensions, utility relocations,new double-wide bridge at Yonge St., and King City GO Station Infrastructure Improvements . The Project will be delivered by two construction contracts (DBB):Phase 1 includes enabling works between Mi 24.6 and 26.5.Phase 2 includes enabling works between Mi 21.1 to 24.6 and 26.5 to 29.17, new Yonge St. bridge and King City GO StationInfrastructure Improvements.

Project: Allandale Mobility Hub and Downtown Connection Hub - Construction
Description: The site will include bus platforms, lay by express bus stops, and a terminal building. The Downtown Connection Hub will function as the primary bus stop within the Downtown by providing lay by lanes and bus stops with a shelter to serve the Downtown with the relocation of the primary terminal to the site adjacent to the Allandale Waterfront GO Station.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Purchase and commissioning of 32 replacement urban transit buses (40' diesel), including theinstallation of all additional equipment required for in-service use.

Description: Refurbish approximately 300 buses, including around 112 conventional buses and 41 hybrid buses.

Description: Build a new transit hub. This will increase the number of bus bays from seven to 16,  and include new bus canopies, an interior rider waiting area, concessions and new washroom facilities.
Result: Increased capacity of the terminal, doubling the number of passenger trips from 15,000 to approx. 30,000 daily trips, or an additional 2.1M trips annually.

Description: Purchase 13 conventional diesel buses and 8 specialized gasoline buses.

Description: Replacing or rehabilitate approximately 50 total bus pads and shelters in Brantford.

Description: The scope of the project includes the replacement of two transit hoists; improvements to the buswash system including the replacement of brushes, motors and pumps; and a fuel pumpreplacement project which includes the replacement of 3 existing pumps including valves,plumbing, electrical and safety equipment.

Project: Transit Terminal and Bus Shelter Purchases and Rehabilitation
Description: Upgrades to the main bus terminal (including a fully accessible, enclosed area) and the installation of six new solar powered bus shelters on inter-urban routes will provide transit users with a more comfortable and accessible public transit experience.
Result: This project will provide transit users with a more comfortable and accessible public transit experience

Description: Project includes the procurement of five 8-meter low-floor specialized diesel vehicles.
Result: Improved accessibility to the town's transit system.

Description: Purchase 8 new diesel buses, 7 conventional and one para transit buses, over an eight-year period as well as renewing major power train components to extend the useful life of six buses.
Result: Improved accessibility and reliability of the transit fleet with less downtime and delays attributed to an aging fleet.

Project: Replacement Conventional and Para Transit Buses
Description: Replace 6 conventional transit buses, 6 electric hybrid diesel buses and 8 specialized paratransit buses, all diesel, from 2020 to 2027 inclusive.
Result: Reduce average age of present transit fleet, from 7 years to 5 years.

Description: Install 90 new cameras and 26 NVR units that operate the cameras, as well as the replacement of existing hardware and software to access surveillance data.
Result: Enhanced security to the public, bus operators and the City’s assets.

Description: Install passenger counters on 15 buses.
Result: Increased ridership data accuracy that can be used to more accurately adjust and create routes for user convenience.

Description: Install new electronic fareboxes on 26 buses.
Result: Provide modern payment options for passengers and increased accuracy in passenger and revenue data collection.

Project: Bus Shelters and Bus Stop Accessibility
Description: Install new bus shelters at high traffic locations and install concrete pads making 60 bus stops fully accessible.
Result: Improved boarding accessibility to conventional buses.

Project: Wifi Commander: Installation of Wireless Video Surveillance
Description: This project consists of the supply, installation, and software license agreements to create wireless bridges for 25 Conventional and Handi Transit buses.  Wireless and automatic video management that automatically downloads video alarms and allows authorized users to search video by time or location.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: The project consists of the implementation of enhanced technology and software for an on-demand scheduling system for passengers.  On-demand micro transit will give the opportunity to reduce operating costs, increase rider-ship, expanding coverage, and providing a reliable transportation option. 10 to 15 Buses will have the software/hardware installed and public portal for On-Demand service.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: The project consists of replacing the current Handi Transit software. The project includes 7 driver tablets, replacing the aging tablets currently being utilized.  The implementation of new Handi Transit software will provide opportunity to enhance service and reliability, in return improving life quality. Software will service 1,359 clients, generating 110 trips per day. customers will be able to utilize a portal to book trips.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Project: Replacement of Metal Sliding and Garage Doors

Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: The project consists of the replacement of an in-ground bus hoist with a new hoist able to lift heavier hybrid buses.

Description: This project involves the construction of Bus Rapid Transit lanes with active transportation corridors on Kingston Rd. in the Town of Ajax, Dundas St. in the Town of Whitby, and Downtown Oshawa.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.

Description: Construct a 10-kilometre north-south bus rapid transit corridor along Simcoe Street from Royal Street north to Highway 407, as well as purchase 8 buses and install new bus shelters.

Description: Purchase 10 hybrid electric buses.
Result: Reduced emissions and fuel costs while providing transit users with a modern, safe, and efficient transit system.

Description: Resurface unpaved bus stops and install accessible bus shelters with solar lighting.
Result: Improved accessibility, safety and comfort for transit users.

Description: Purchase 13 40-foot buses equipped with fare payment collection technology.
Result: Provide transit users with a modern, safe and efficient fleet.

Description: Construct a 9,257 square foot transit operations building.

Description: Purchase two articulated buses for the region's PULSE rapid transit fleet.
Result: Increased capacity along the high-volume bus rapid transit corridor.

Project: Construction of Median BRT Lanes on Highway 2, City of Pickering
Description: This project involves  construction of dedicated median transit lanes, median transit shelters/stops, and dedicated bike lanes along Highway 2 through the City of Pickering.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Rehabilitation of the Rouge River open deck bridge.

Description: Existing station on the Barrie Line

Description: Purchase 53 low-floor 40-foot buses over eight years to replace the older vehicles in the fleet.

Project: Shelter Upgrade and Implementation of Various Technological Improvements
Description: Improvements to 18 outdated transit shelter infrastructure. Review transit technological requirements to improve the rider experience and ease of access to services.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructureImproved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: Install new transportation management and communication technology in the bus fleet, and the replace traffic signal controllers at all intersections.
Result: Safer and higher quality transit system for all passengers.

Description: Construct three major mobility hubs located in the centre, downtown and the south end of the city.
Result: Restructured transit system which will include rapid bus lines to support increased ridership and service needs.

Description: Introduce intersection improvements along three corridors with dedicated turn lanes for buses, passenger waiting areas and shelters, fare vending machines, passenger information signage,  and lighting.
Result: Reduced bus travel times, increased transit ridership, and improved operational efficiency

Description: This project involves the acquisition of a 14-seat accessible bus. With this vehicle, the Municipality of Greenstone will be able to increase services to seniors and expand the specialized transit system currently in place to include all wards within the Municipality to increase access to social & physical activities.
Result: With this vehicle, the Municipality of Greenstone will be able to increase services to seniors and expand the specialized transit system currently in place to include all wards within the Municipality to increase access to social & physical activities.

Existing station on the Kitchener line

Description: Construction of a new GO station
Result: North track, station building, 40 parking spaces, and a dedicated kiss and ride area are open for public use (as of July 9, 2015). Work continues until late 2016 on the south track, pedestrian bridge from Bay Street and an additional 260 parking spaces.
Indoor storage for up to 40 buses, service bays for fuelling, bus wash, inspection, cleaning and repairs.

Description: Construction of new bus terminal
Result: Five plaforms for Hamilton Street Railway (HSR) buses - four on campus and a fifth on a protected shoulder on West 5th street - and a ""bus only"" roadway.

Description: Project consists of seven strategic active transportation elements. These include: •	a 185m active transportation bridge that crosses the Lincoln Alexander Parkway, connecting McQuesten Park and Limeridge Mall, •	1.4 km of new cycle tracks along Bay Street;•	1.2 km Mountain Brow multi-use path;•	2.2 km Dundas St. multi-use path;•	Approximately 17.765 km of new sidewalks in various locations;•	500 new bicycle parking spaces; and•	30 new bike-share stations.
Result: Improved capacity

Project: Implement Priority Bus Measures along A-Line Corridor
Description: Project scope to include realignment of A-Line route from John Street to James Street and introduce transit signal priority at ~26 intersections along Upper James/James St corridor.

Project: Replacement of Birch Avenue Bridge and Associated Road Works/Construction of Salt Management Facility
Description: The project involves the conversion of Birch Avenue from one-way travel southbound to two-way travel northbound and southbound. The project will also construct a salt management facility to replace the current facility to be demolished at the site of the new MSF.
Result: Improved Quality and/or safety of existing or future transit systems.

Project: Expansion of Transit Fleet to Support Service Growth
Description: This project includes the purchase of up to 85 forty-foot Compressed Natural Gas buses.

Description: This project includes the procurement of approximately 72 forty-foot Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) buses and 20 sixty-foot CNG buses to replace buses that have reached the end of their lifecycle.

Description: This project involves the construction of a new maintenance and storage facility.

Description: The Hamilton LRT project will play a key role in the revitalization of Hamilton’s urban environment by transforming how residents travel across the heart of the city. Modern light rail service will connect key areas, destinations and institutions along Main Street, King Street and Queenston Road, creating a 14 kilometre multi-modal corridor and an enhanced streetscape. The LRT will feature 17 stops.
Result: The province, with funding support from the federal government, is advancing this LRT project that will offer frequent and reliable connections on the 14-kilometre line from Eastgate Square through downtown Hamilton to McMaster University.
Address: 116 King St E (Community Office) 100 King St W, Hamilton, Ont (Project Office)

Description: The planning project consists of undertaking a detailed design review of two existing transit hubs, and a functional design review of five new hubs across the City of Hamilton, Ontario.

Description: The project scope includes the procurement and delivery of up to fifteen (15) accessible transit vehicles and up to four (4) accessible supervisor vehicles, all of which will be equipped with dispatching software to enable vehicle location tracking.

Description: Purchase one additional bus and replace a para-transit bus.

Description: Purchase a long-range electric battery bus equipped with farebox technology and GPS, and install battery charging equipment at the bus depot.

Description: Construct various trails, sidewalks and pedestrian crossovers.

Description: Reconstruct the intersection at King St. West and Portsmouth Avenue to include a dedicated bus lane and relocated bus stops.

Description: Construct a new designated bike lane, a multi-use path, and a new sidewalk.

Description: Construct 12 transit passenger stations at bus stops with  lighting, waste and recycling bins, bike storage and more.

Result: Re-design and construction of Montreal Street at John Counter Boulevard to support public transit and active transportation improvements.

Description: Install various transit priority equipment and traffic control upgrades.
Result: Improved public transit reliability and increase service frequency.

Project: Enhanced Pedestrian-Cycling Connections - East-West Corridors Project - phase 2
Description: The project scope includes construction of 2.5 km of new off-road separated cycling facilities, 3.9 km of new multi-use pathways and 0.75 km of new sidewalks, as well as associated upgrades to intersections along these areas.

Project: Enhanced Pedestrian-Cycling Pathway and Sidewalk Connections to Kingston Transit Bus Stops - phase 2
Description: The project consists of constructing approximately 1.5km of off-road trails, 2.7km of sidewalks to eliminate identified gaps in the sidewalk network, and 10 pedestrian crossings, in the City of Kingston.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: The project involves the reconstruction and improvement to sidewalk connections and crosswalks; road improvements to implement shared cycling lanes; and geometric improvements to the Union Street and King Street intersection to improve pedestrian safety and visibility.

Description: Purchase 2 low-floor conventional diesel buses to replace existing buses which have reached the end of their operational life.

Description: Project includes upgrading up to 399 intersections into a highbandwidth communication network, installation of transit-priority signals and GPS-based tracking sensors, installation of video cameras and travel time monitoring equipment, and the creation of a Transportation Management Centre within an existing municipal building to centralize and coordinate traffic management capabilities across the City of London.
Result: The Project will improve the data collection, analysis and dispatch capabilities of theCity of London, ensuring greater reliability of the existing and future transit system.

Description: The Project consists of the construction of new bicycle lanes and improved sidewalksbetween the Thames Valley Parkway and transit stops along the planned DowntownLoop Bus Rapid Transit
Result: The Project will deliver 0.4 km of new bicycle lanes, 0.4 km of improved sidewalks, and 0.25km of reconstructed roadway.

Description: This project involves revitalizing the roadway from downtown to Fanshawe College by widening Highbury Bridge (overpass), Highbury Avenue and Oxford Street as well as conversion of existing mixed use traffic lanes into dedicated bus lanes.

Description: The Project involves the construction of a Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) corridor in downtown London, including dedicated bus lanes, intelligent traffic signals, platforms and bicycle lanes, as well as the relocation and reconstruction of sidewalks and water mains impacted by construction of the corridor.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.
Address: Queens Ave & Wellington St.Ridout St & King St

Project: Adelaide Street Underpass Active Transportation Connections
Description: The Project is a component of the broader Adelaide Street Underpass Project and will construct approx. 250m of four-metre wide multi-use paths on both sides (500m total) of Adelaide Street which will run under a Canadian Pacific Rail bridge.
Result: Currently, Adelaide Street crosses two tracks at-grade directly adjacent to a CPR yard on the eastern side of the intersection. The Project will facilitate active transit that provides a connection to bus stops on Adelaide street and to future bus rapid transit on Oxford Street. The crossing will eliminate frequent delays due to train blockages.

Description: This project involves the construction of a complete Rapid Transit corridor along Wellington Rd. from downtown to Highway 401 and includes widening to establish continuous transit lanes, multi-use paths, bike lanes, and sidewalks.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.

Project: Dundas Street Old East Village Streetscape Improvements
Description: The Project scope includes the widening of approximately 1.62 kilometers of roadway along Dundas St. replacement of adjacent sidewalks, installation of approximately 0.81 kilometers of new dedicated cycling lanes with signalized intersections at Dundas St. & Lyle St. /Elizabeth St. and Dundas St. & Rectory St., and installation of new bicycle parking & lock-up areas.
Result: The Project will enhance and revitalize the transit corridor in the area of Dundas street with improved direct pedestrian and cycling connections to Dundas street bus stops and along connecting side streets to the future King Street rapid transit corridor.
Address: Dundas St. & Lyle St./Elizabeth St. Dundas St. & Rectory St.

Description: Purchase 31 mixed 40' and 60' diesel buses.

Description: Expansion of the Thames Valley Parkway including approximately 750 linear meters of new 3.0-meter-wide asphalt pathway and a new pedestrian bridge.
Result: Improved capacity and/or quality of pathways and/or active transportation infrastructure

Description: The project consists of improving 20-35 pedestrian crossovers (PXOs) with newly upgraded traffic control devices which meet Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities (AODA) requirements. AODA compliant infrastructure including tactile plates and accessible pedestrian buttons.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: The scope of work includes reconstructing traffic signal components to be AODA compliant.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: Project includes the planning, design and construction of one to three bike parking structures that include bike locking features, shelter, and amenities such as benches lighting and signage. Project is planning to include 60 -75 bike parking spaces.

Description: Build a new garage for a bus used to transport senior citizens.

Description: Replace one 30-foot transit buses and two specialized transit vans.

Project: Design and Construction of a Transit Operations Facility
Description: The project involves the design and construction of a Transit Operations Facility (Phase 1) to satisfy storage and servicing needs of the public transit fleet. The project's scope includes site development, detailed design and construction of a new Transit Operations Facility, 147,863 square feet, applying sustainable design practices, and using LEED criteria. The facility will provide storage space for 36 conventional and specialized vehicles with a total build-out capacity for 70 vehicles as well as space for vehicle servicing and maintenance.
Result: The project will result in improved quality and safety of the existing and future transit system in Milton, Ontario.

Description: 18 kilometre light rail transit, featuring 19 stops and travelling through two urban growth centres and connecting to major transit systems including GO Transit, Mississauga Transitway, Brampton Transit, ZUM and MiWay
Result: The 18-kilometre Hazel McCallion Line will bring a new, environmentally friendly and reliable method of transportation to a rapidly growing region. The new transit system will feature 19 stops, travel through two urban growth centres and connect to major transit systems including GO Transit (Milton and Lakeshore West lines), the Mississauga Transitway, Brampton Transit, ZUM and MiWay. The Hazel McCallion Line will operate in its own dedicated lane ensuring a smooth, reliable and convenient ride along the region’s busiest street.

Project: Construction of a new bus rapid transit corridor along Lakeshore Road in Mississauga
Description: This project will provide two-way centre-running bus rapid transit lanes and median BRT stop platforms on Lakeshore Road from East Avenue to Deta Road in the City of Mississauga.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.

Project: Enhanced Stop Amenities for Priority (Express) Bus Corridors
Description: The project scope includes the procurement of services and installation of up to 89 large transit stop shelters that will be fully heated, include doors that meet provincial accessibility standard, and new digital signage. The shelters will be installed within four Frequent Rapid Transit Network Bus Priority Corridor.
Result: The project will result in improved capacity, quality, safety and improved access to the public transit system in Mississauga, Ontario

Description: The project involves the rehabilitation of major bus components and subsystems throughout the existing public transit fleet of 500 conventional diesel and diesel-hybrid buses to extend their service life-cycle with improved reliability.
Result: The project will result in improved quality, safety, and accessibility of the transit system in Mississauga, Ontario.

Project: ITS Hardware and Software Upgrade in Transit Buses
Description: The Project will replace the CAD/AVL/MDT unit on approximately 300 transit buses, upgrade the back-end Bus Scheduling software (HASTUS) along with Bus Monitoring/Tracking, software(Transit Master); upgrade other ITS Equipment (cameras, dvr) on all 300 buses; and upgrade/activate the software/module which helps with vehicle component monitoring (Bus Intelligence).
Result: The project will result in improved quality of the transit system in Mississauga, Ontario.

Description: This project will involve the installation of 210 new bus shelters at existing bus stops. Shelter types include solar powered lighting, hydro powered lighting and ad panel lighting.
Result: Increased quality and safety within on-street transit shelters due to enhanced lighting and visibility of customers awaiting pick-up.

Description: This project consists of the installation of one shelter at each of four (4) bus terminals. The project will deliver heated shelters with digitized signage at the Laird/Vega Bus Loop, Meadowvale Town Centre, Erin Mills Town Centre and Dixie Outlet Mall.
Result: The project will result in increased quality of, and access to, the transit system in Mississauga, Ontario.

Project: New and/or Rehabilitation of Bus Stop Pads
Description: The project involves the installation of new bus stop pads and rehabilitation of existing ones to ensure that bus stops are fully accessible.
Result: The project will lead to improved quality and accessibility of the public transit system in the City of Mississauga, Ontario.

Project: Replacement of Stop Markers with New Accessible Design
Description: Purchase and installation of 3325 bus poles and 6650 stop markers. Stop markers will be printed accordingto a new accessible design to be implemented system wide (at all bus stops).
Result: The project will result in improved quality and safety of the transit system and improved access to a public transit system in Mississauga, Ontario.

Description: The project scope includes construction of enhanced glass partitions on top of an existing median concrete jersey barriers that separate the buses travelling in different directions at seven stations along the Mississauga Transitway. The seven stations are located at Central Parkway Station, Cawthra Station, Tomken Station, Dixie Station, Tahoe Station, Etobicoke Creek Station, and Spectrum Station.
Result: The project will result in improved safety of public transit system infrastructure in the City of Mississauga, Ontario.

Description: The project scope includes various transit assets including two new accessible passenger pick-up layby’s, public facing signage to provide customer safety information at 17 locations and additional pylon signage at City Centre Transit Terminal (CCTT) and Westwood stations.
Result: The project will result in improved quality, and safety of existing and future public transit system infrastructure as well as improved access to the public transit system in the City of Mississauga, Ontario.

Description: Project scope includes the procurement of 10 zero-emission battery electric vehicles to replace existing non-electric transit support vehicles for purposes such as driver change-off, supervisor transportation and maintenance within the City's non-revenue transit fleet.
Result: The project will result in improved quality and safety of the transit system in Mississauga, Ontario.

Description: Refurbish the farebox system in 530 buses.
Result: Extended useful life, improved quality and accessibility of the transit system.

Description: This project involves the purchase of hybrid buses through the Mississauga Bus Replacement Program.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure.

Project: Transit Priority Measures (Infrastructure) for Priority (Express) Bus Corridors
Description: The Project involves implementation of transit priority measures to improve and enhance three Mississauga bus corridors identified within the City Right of Way (ROW). The project will construct queue jump lanes at 25 intersections on both approaches (i.e., 2 at each intersection) for a total of 16 on Derry Rd., 16 on Eglinton Rd., and 18 on Dixie Rd. Total length of assets is ~0.6km (~12m per queue jump lane).
Result: Improve quality and safety of the existing transit system with safety related and operational improvements

Project: MiWay Bus Garages: Modifications for Electric Buses
Description: Design and implementation of modifications to bus storage and maintenance garages to accommodate the addition of battery electric buses to the public transit fleet.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Replace the transmission on six buses.

Result: THis will increase the longevity of buses  by reducing their exposure to the elements.

Project: GO Expansion: Lakeshore East, West Corridor Expansion
Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: The Lakeshore East Grading project – West, between Pape Avenue and Kenney Road includes: grading, retaining walls and construction of a new culvert to accommodate the fourth track. Danforth Avenue, Warden Avenue and Woodbine Avenue bridge expansions.

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works

The OnCorr project includes the remaining On Corridor work necessary to deliver the GO Expansion Service Levels plus the fleet required to run the service. The Project also includes the Operation and Maintenance of the OnCorr infrastructure and the fleet for a 25 year period starting from Financial Close. The maintenance and operation requirements are for the GO-owned network to Burlington, Bramalea, Barrie, Lincolnville, and Oshawa, as well as operation of GO services over CN and CP lines to Hamilton, Niagara, Kitchener, Milton, and Richmond Hill. Project Co. will also have to ensure that the track network, signalling system, energy system, communications system, safety system, network control system and Trains all function as an integrated system to deliver the Train Service.
GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Design and construction of a new, two-track tunnel under the Highway 401/409 interchange, including grading, retaining walls, and related works from west of Islington Avenue to east of Kipling Avenue. To help increase capacity on the Kitchener Corridor, which passes under Highway 401/409 through a tunnel

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: To help increase capacity on the Barrie Corridor. Eliminates the existing at-grade crossing at Mile 4.6 between the single-track GO Newmarket subdivision and the two tracks of the CP North Toronto Subdivision.

Description: Build 9.2 kilometers of new light rail transit extension from Mount Dennis Station to Renforth Drive.
Result: The proposed extension of the Eglinton Crosstown LRT will run 9.2 kilometres from the future Mount Dennis LRT station to Renforth Drive and will operate mainly underground, helping to reduce travel times and improve access to jobs, schools and other destinations throughout the Greater Toronto Area.

Description: Approximately 8-kilometre extension of the TTC's existing Line 2 subway, with three proposed stops, from Kennedy Station to a new terminus at Sheppard Avenue and McCowan Road
Result: The Scarborough Subway Extension is a 7.8 kilometre extension of TTC's Line 2 Bloor-Danforth Subway, from the existing Kennedy Station northeast to McCowan Road/Sheppard Avenue. The line will include three new stations at Lawrence Avenue and McCowan Road, Scarborough Centre and a terminal station at McCowan Road and Sheppard Avenue.

Description: New 15.6km, 15-stop subway line running from Exhibition Station, through downtown, all the way to the Eglinton Crosstown LRT at Don Mills and Eglinton.
Result: The Ontario Line is a 15.6-kilometre is a new subway line that will connect the Ontario Science Centre to Exhibition/Ontario Place. Over half of the route is planned to run underground through new tunnels, with the remainder running along elevated and at-grade track. The Ontario Line will include fifteen stations, with numerous connections to the broader transit network, including GO Transit rail services, the Toronto Transit Commission's subway Lines 1 and 2, the future Line 5 (Eglinton Crosstown LRT), as well as numerous bus and streetcar routes.

Project: Stouffville Stations and Grade Separations - Agincourt, Milliken, Unionville
Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: New passenger pick-up and drop-off area (Kiss & Ride), more bicycle storage, improved pedestrian connections to Sheppard Avenue at the south end of both platforms. New pedestrian tunnels and elevators at the north and south end of the station. A new, LEED certified station building. New second platform and a relocated east platform, both with new snow-melting systems to give customers more convenient access to trains running in both directions. Canopies over the platforms with shelters to protect customers from the elements. A second track to support two-way, all day service so trains can travel both ways on the Stouffville line.
Address: Agincourt, Milliken and Unionville GO stations

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Two new tunnels with elevator access to the platform, new heated shelters, canopies and snow melting systems on the platforms, two new kiss & rides, bicycle/pedestrian paths and new bicycle shelters, new access to the station from the south side.

Project: Lakeshore West Corridor Expansion - Long Branch Station Rehabilitation
Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: New accessible west tunnel with elevator and stair connections to platform level, new accessible east pedestrian access and all related elements (elevators etc), new east entrance building with barrier-free washrooms and waiting area, revisions to existing parking lot, new bicycle storage room, rehabilitation of existing platforms, improved access from Edgeware Drive.

Project: Union Station Train Control (aka USRC Signalling System)
Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Implementation of a modernized system to reduce signal disruptions, improve reliability and allow trains to move faster, while maintaining GO's high safety standards. This project also includes work on the cable network, retaining walls, maintenance acces

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: Modern, centralized, automatic train control system to interface with the new Union Station Rail Corridor Signalling System and meet the increasing capacity and reliability needs of the GO Transit rail network

Description: New GO Station

Description: Stations
Result: Work to upgrade Eglinton GO Station and make it fully accessible will include: two new tunnels, stairwells and elevators to platforms, mini-platforms to enable boarding and exiting accessibility coaches, tactile edge tiles, new ramps, digital signage and rehabilitation of the pick-up, drop-off zone.

Description: Part of the Ontario Line, a new 15.6-km, 15-stop subway line running from Exhibition Station, through downtown, all the way to the Eglinton Crosstown LRT at Don Mills and Eglinton.
Result: Expected to accommodate 388,000 rides each day, cut commute times by as much as 40 minutes, and reduce daily car trips by 28,000. It will feature more than 40 connections to other transit options and reduce crowding at the TTC's existing Bloor-Yonge, Eglinton and Union stations by 22 per cent, 16 per cent, and 14 per cent respectively.

Description: The project will purchase a new gasoline vehicle to replace the existing, aging diesel vehicle used by the rural transit program.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: New Toronto-York Spadina Subway Extension station
Result: 8.6 kilometre extension from Sheppard West (formerly Downsview) station northwest through York University and north to the Vaughan Metropolitan Centre

Description: New Toronto-York Spadina Subway Extension station
Result: 8.6 kilometre extension from Sheppard West (formerly Downsview) station northwest through York University and north to the Vaughan Metropolitan Centre

Project: Rutherford GO Station Grade Separation and Parking Structure
Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: The Rutherford GO Station package includes a new multi-level parking garage, a new station building, upgraded pick-up and drop-off, new bus loop with seamless connections to York Region Transit, 100 indoor secure bike parking spaces, and double track with new east platform. Metrolinx also built a grade separation on Rutherford Road from Westburne Drive to Peter Rupert Avenue that enhances community safety and prevents drivers from having to wait at the rail crossing.

Description: Maple GO Station
Existing station on the Barrie Line
Construction of a 18-bay bus terminal
Result: Connecting GO bus, York Region VIVA transit and TTC services, will include 600 parking spaces and pick-up and drop-off area

Description: Purchase nine buses, construct several transit shelters, provide bus stop improvements, and create a Transit Master Plan.
Result: Increased accessibility, capacity, and quality of the public transit system.

Description: This project involved construction of light rail travels between Conestoga station in Waterloo and Fairway station in Kitchener, with a total of 19 stations along the route. At Fairway station, ION light rail connects to ION bus (Route 302) and travels to the Ainslie Street Terminal in Cambridge.
Result: Improved mobility and transportation user-experience.
Highway / Transit Line: Waterloo ION Rapid Transit. Project expected to open in December 2018, but is facing schedule risks.

Project: Grand River Transit - Additional Conventional Buses
Description: Purchase 15 diesel buses.
Result: Improved public transit system capacity in the Regional Municipality of Waterloo.

Project: Grand River Transit - Replacement of MobilityPLUS Vehicles
Description: Replacement of 19 specialized transit buses.
Result: Improved capacity, reliability and access to the specialized transit services in the Regional Municipality of Waterloo.

Project: Grand River Transit - Purchase of Additional MobilityPLUS Vehicles
Description: Purchase 2 specialized service buses.
Result: Improved capacity, reliability and access to the specialized transit services in the Regional Municipality of Waterloo.

Project: Grand River Transit - Conventional Bus Replacement
Description: Purchase 15 new clean diesel buses to replace existing buses.
Result: Improved quality and safety of the Waterloo Region's transit system.

Description: Waterloo ION station. The northern end of the ION route.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located along the existing rail corridor on Northfield Drive West, close to Parkdale.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, situated on the rail line between Columbia and Bearinger.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located between Engineering 5 and Davis Centre buildings on the University of Waterloo campus.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station linked to Uptown Waterloo neighbourhood. It serves those heading north from Allen.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Construction of light rail transit between Conestoga Mall (Waterloo) and Fairview Park Mall (Kitchener ), and bus rapid transit between Fairview Park Mall and the Ainslie Street Terminal (Cambridge).
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located in the centre of the road, at the intersection of King and Allen.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located in the centre of the road right in front of Grand River Hospital.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located within the City of Kitchener's Innovation District, in the heart of a transformed downtown neighbourhood.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, serving southbound trips.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, serving northbound trips. Nearby destinations include St Mary's Church and the Kitchener Downtown Community Centre.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: The second of two ION stops serving downtown Kitchener, providing access to the Waterloo Region Courthouse.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station serving southbound trips.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, serving several adjoining residential areas including the established Cameron Heights neighbourhood.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, which links to GRT and future iXpress service along Ottawa.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Waterloo ION station, located within a residential neighbourhood, beside the Central Baptist Church.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: Construction of light rail transit between Conestoga Mall (Waterloo) and Fairview Park Mall (Kitchener ), and bus rapid transit between Fairview Park Mall and the Ainslie Street Terminal (Cambridge).
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: A key connection point on the ION route, linking LRT in Kitchener with adapted bus rapid transit, which extends south to the Ainslie Street transit terminal in Cambridge. It is an important gateway to GRT, providing access to numerous local bus routes as well as iXpress services.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: Ottawa Street at Highway 7 to King Street Reconstruction (Including Bike lanes)
Description: Reconstruction of 0.86 km of roadway and construction of 1.72 km of new bike lanes on Ottawa Street from King Street to Highway 7.
Result: The bike lanes will provide a continuous cycling route along Ottawa Street from adjacent bike lanes, connecting to the new Borden Avenue ION rapid transit station.

Description: Construct a pedestrian and cycling bridge at Highway 7/8.
Result: Improved active transportation options for residents and increased access to the public transit system

Description: Construction of a 1.9 km multi-use trail on  Lackner Boulevard.
Result: Expanded active transportation network and improved connectivity to the public transit system.

Description: Expand the Conestoga College Doon Campus transit station and purchase 6 new conventional diesel buses.
Result: Safer and more efficient public transit system.

Project: Market Trail to ION Light Rail Transit
Description: Construct a 1.7 km shared-use active transportation trail to ION Light Rail Transit, including 10 bike racks, improvements at 3 road crossings, and the installation of new LED lighting.
Result: Improved and safer access the light-rail transit system  for pedestrians and cyclists.

Description: Add 15 new road crossings, 5 km of new pedestrian walkways and bike lanes to the Iron Horse Trail, connecting to public transit stops.
Result: Improved safety for cyclists and pedestrians when using the trail and public transit in the area.

Description: Renovate 60 bus stops with new hard surface pads, build 10 bus shelters and improvements made to 2 pedestrian crossings and 10 intersections.
Result: Increased safety and accessibility of the transit system.

Description: Install 30 new digital information displays at LRT platforms and 9 new on-board information displays. Upgrades  to the mobile payment app, as well as to 36 mobile payment validation machines and 25 point-of-sale units.
Result: Improved operation of public transit, and greater convenience for transit riders.

Description: Construct several heated bus shelters and bike storage areas at the University of Waterloo bus station.
Result: Improved passenger experience and accessibility to the transit system.

Description: Project includes the construction of 1 km of cycling lanes on Hespeler Rd. from Eastbound Ramp to 401 to Westbound Ramp to 401.
Result: Improved connections to Groh Avenue and to Pinebush Road, which are adjacent to numerous bus routes.

Description: Construct a new transit operations facility in the City of Welland on the same site as the current facility.
Result: Improved capacity and quality of the public transit infrastructure in Welland.

Description: Purchase a specialized accessible bus to replace the existing bus that is nearing the end of its operational life.
Result: More reliable and safer service to more remote areas of the community.

Project: GO Transit East Rail Maintenance Facility
Description: Construction of a new maintenance facility
Result: 500,000 sq. ft. space dedicated to mechanical maintenance, body repair, day-to-day cleaning; additional storage for up to 13 12-car GO Transit passenger trains.
Address: South Blair St / Victoria St E

Description: GO Expansion - Early Works
Result: The layover expansion will add an additional three storage tracks as required to support the increase in service to meet GO Expansion (previously RER) service growth projections. The project also includes the realignment of existing storage tracks to accommodate turnouts for the additional tracks, realignment of the Maintenance-Of-Way (MOW) tracks, and upgrades to the existing  systems, including electrical, drainage, fuelling, communication, and mechanical systems, as well as, decommissioning of the existing station services infrastructure upon completion of the new Lincolnville GO Station.

Description: Replace 8 buses in 2020 and 8 buses in 2021 that have exceeded their useful life. Plus purchase 5 expansion buses and up to 2 new supervisor support vans.
Result: Improved customerexperience and reliability of service.

Description: Construct 4.4 kms of bicycle lanes and accessible sidewalks on Grand Marais Road from  Dougall Avenue to Dominion Boulevard.
Result: Safer active transportation along Grand Marais Road.

Project: Construction of Dougall Avenue including Bike lanes and Sidewalks
Description: Construction of 220 metres of new bike lanes and sidewalks on each side of Dougall Avenue, between Ouellette Place and Eugenie Street.
Result: This will improve access to the public transit system.

Description: Construct sidewalks, bicycle lanes, multi-use trails and pedestrian bridges on existing transit routes throughout the city.
Result: Improved access to the public transit system.

Description: Improve 19.29 kms of sidewalk to better link Windsor residents to the transit system.
Result: Improved capacity and/or quality of pathways and/or active transportation infrastructure

Project: Pedestrian Crossover Installation in Six Locations
Description: This project includes the installation of six pedestrian crossings at the following locations: Drouillard Road at Richmond Street, University Avenue West at Patricia Street, Lauzon Road at Clairview Avenue, Wyandotte St. E. at Marentette, Wyandotte St. W at Dougall, and Forest Glade Dr. at Rosebriar.
Result: Improved access and safety for pedestrians.

Project: Transit Terminals, New Pedestrian Bus Shelters and Customer Amenities
Description: Upgrade various components of transit stops throughout the  city, including a minimum of 70 new passenger shelters and upgrading existing ones to make them more accessible, new bike facilities and new signage.
Result: Improved capacity and accessibility of the public transit system.

Description: Construct over 3 kms of designated bike lanes and sidewalks along Cabana Road West from Dougall Avenue to Rankin Avenue.
Result: Improved access to the public transit system.

Project: Implementation of the Windsor Transit Master Plan
Description: A design study to evaluate the costs of improving various aspects of the public transit system, as well as the installation of new signage and decals for the re-branding of the transit system, and new route scheduling software and an intelligent transportation system.
Result: Improved public transit system.

Project: Quantification of Ridership Through The Use of Automatic Passenger Counters (APC's)
Description: The project will purchase and install automatic passenger counters for the bus fleet.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Project: Acquisition of process equipment to support the bus rehabilitation program.
Description: The project consists of the replacement of equipment in a transit garage in the City of Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: The project consists of upgrading and expanding the Transit Windsor Garage in order to be able to store more buses and to improve it’s maintenance capacity and operational efficiency in the City of Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Description: The project consists of renovating office space and conducting improvements to the mechanical systems of a transit garage in the City of Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: Replacement of existing rolling stock vehicles (34 buses)
Description: The project consists of procuring up to 34 standard, 40-foot hybrid electric buses to replace aging fleet stock in Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: Transit Garage Site Work, Exterior Renovations and Electrical Upgrades
Description: The project consists of replacing and/or repairing electrical components and site features of the Transit Garage in Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: East End Terminal Relocation and Bus Stop Amenities
Description: The project will construct a new terminal station and improve bus stops in Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: West End Terminal Upgrades - Detailed Design and Construction
Description: This project consists of upgrading the St. Clair College and Hotel Dieu Healthcare Terminals in the City of Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved capacity of public transit infrastructure

Project: Planning and Procurement of Service Delivery Enhancements
Description: The project will review the existing public transit system to evaluate, purchase, and implement new technologies in Windsor, Ontario.
Result: Improved quality and/or safety of existing and future public transit

Description: The construction of an automatic bus wash building that will increase the life span of buses.
Result: It is expected the project will improve quality of service and extend bus life cycle through cleaner buses as well as increase efficiency and cost savings through better and quicker automaticcleaning compared to manual cleaning.

Description: Construction of dedicated rapidways along the existing Highway 7, Yonge Street and Davis Drive VIVA corridors
Result: Making it easier and faster to travel in and around York Region and to connect to transit across Greater Toronto and Hamilton Area

Description: Approximately 8 kilometre extension of Line 1 north from Finch Station to the Richmond Hill/Langstaff Gateway Urban Centre at Highway 7.
Result: The Yonge North Subway Extension will bring the TTC’s Line 1 service north from Finch Station to Vaughan, Markham and Richmond Hill. The latest plans propose five stations along an extension of roughly 8 kilometres.

Project: Launch shaft early works site - Yonge North Subway Extension
Description: Part of the Yonge North Subway Extension, an approximately 8 kilometre extension of Line 1 north from Finch Station to the Richmond Hill/Langstaff Gateway Urban Centre at Highway 7.
Result: The Yonge North Subway Extension will bring the TTC’s Line 1 service north from Finch Station to Vaughan, Markham and Richmond Hill. The latest plans propose five up to four stations along an extension of roughly 8 kilometres.
